questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag the commands on the left that are enabled during a SSH or Telnet session with a lightweight AP and drop them on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//
What is the approximate time difference for a client to perform an intracontroller roam compared to an intercontroller roam?

discussion.content: The ~approximate time difference for a client to perform the intracontroller roam about 10 ms faster when compared to the intercontroller roam

This question is not specific enough, such that there is not one correct answer.
An intra-controller roam (same controller) is said to complete in "less than 10ms".

An Inter-controller roam can take a widely varying amount of time depending on many things, such as if it is a layer 2 or layer 3 roam, if the controllers are in the same mobility group, or if the roam involves the core of the network or not. 

An Inter-controller roam which is a layer 2 roam on the same subnet is said to take "less than 20ms", which is where the 10ms difference comes from, however the question is not that specific.

Since an Inter-controller roam will take subsequently longer depending on varying levels of complexity, you can't say it will take 20ms, or any specific number unless you specify that is is not roaming at layer 3, traversing the core, and does not involve any DHCP or authentication actions from the client.

Think back to the 4 mac addresses that can be used in a wireless frame
 Receiver Address, Sender Address, Destination Address, part 4 is usually empty unless you are using Bridging/Mesh, then thats the Mesh APs Mac. 

So the correct answer AP (RA), Host A (SA), HostB (DA), Empty, is correct based on what is in the frame to allow it to travel through the network.

comments.content:
absolutely agree, 4 addresses , 
add 1 RA, add 2 TA, add 3 DA, add 4 empty(ap to ap) ... from official cert guide

discussion.content: Strange question. Could someone have any text on how the data flow from wireless client to wired client? HostA to AP to Host B makes no sense as AP never connect directly to the wired clients(never seen such examples). Some type of switch has to be there.

OK sorry, here is my final answer.
Correct answer is what I first posted: 
Host A
AP 
HOST B

The traffic will not go through the controller to reach a wired client.
it will be passed to the AP and then to the switched network and routed to the wired client at the distribution layer.

Sorry, I missed that host B is a WIRED client.
In that case, the correct answer is:
Host A
AP
Controller 
Host B

The controller acts as the bridge between the wireless and wired networks.

Correct answer is:
Host A
AP
Host B

This question seems to be here twice and the other has the answer correct.

DRAG DROP -
Match the interface description on the left with the appropriate interface on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
-Used for L3 communication between the WLC and LAP
-Designed to be analogous to VLAN for WLAN client device
-This interface is the only consistency "pingable" in-band interface IP Address on the WLC
-The only port that is active when the controller is in boot mode
-Used to support mobility management, DHCP Relay, and Guest Web Auth

http://www.firewall.cx/cisco-technical-knowledgebase/cisco-wireless/1077-cisco-wireless-controllers-interfaces-ports-functionality.html

I agree with Coffee.
Management interface is for control only and does not interface with clients directly in any way. 

Virtual interface interfaces with clients and exists only on the AP, not on the WLC.
Management and virtual answers must be reversed.
